repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Emergency Municipal
            Services Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for West Bank and Gaza -
            Emergency Municipal Services Rehabilitation Project (EMSRP)
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was high, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: The EMSRP
            experience confirms that it is possible to incorporate
            modest institutional reform agenda even in emergency
            projects, provided that there is close supervision,
            effective policy dialogue and adequate time to develop and
            implement the institutional activities. While the
            preparation of emergency projects on a fast track may be
            lauded as demonstrating high responsiveness to immediate
            needs on the ground they may also suffer in terms of not
            focusing in sufficient depth during project preparation to
            important matters like the design of impact monitoring
            indicators. Even in emergency operating situations, it is
            important to be pragmatic in determining the extent to which
            funds should be allocated without detriment to the overall outcome.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Emergency Municipal
            Services Rehabilitation Project : sixth quality of
            supervision assessment (QSA6) - summary assessment sheet

abstracts.cdata!:
The quality of supervision of the
            Emergency Municipal Services Rehabilitation Project for West
            Bank (WB) and Gaza was judged to be highly satisfactory. The
            main problems encounters are: 1) the security situation
            worsened early in project implementation, and remains
            difficult; (b) putting in place the management agent for the
            Municipal Fund (MF) was delayed by over a year, slowing
            progress on creation of the MF; and (c) delays in fulfilling
            eligibility criteria by municipalities for access to second
            year funding. The panel considered the efforts of the task
            team to work in the difficult environment to be commendable,
            not only their intentions, but also their results. Project
            design relied on the staying power of municipalities that
            had been operating in the difficult environment all along.
            Additional support made available to them via the project
            was able to be marshaled with the support of technical
            assistance contractors who worked effectively in reaching
            the scattered project municipalities. The Bank's
            strategy of supervision called for a strong local presence
            in both WB and in Gaza, and flexibility to work
            opportunistically to visit project sites as and when possible.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Emergency Municipal
            Services Rehabilitation Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Municipal Services
            Rehabilitation Project in the West Bank and Gaza, entails
            construction works, and operation of sewage and water
            supply, cleaning of networks regarding water, wastewater,
            and storm drainage, as well as construction of buildings,
            roads, and electricity rehabilitation. This will potentially
            generate water line breaks, dust emissions, noise
            disturbances, in addition to pollution resulting from
            construction debris, and/or toxic gases emanating from
            manholes, and other facilities. This environmental
            assessment stipulates mitigation measures as follows. A
            survey of existing facilities will be conducted during the
            design face to establish appropriate work schedules (limited
            to day times), provide traffic safety regulations, and
            enforce waste disposal regulations, while a re-vegetation
            plan will be implemented following construction. Waste
            disposal will be strictly controlled and monitored for
            disposal at selected (sanitary) landfills; this includes the
            provision of equipment to facilitate flushing, hosing, and
            cleaning, as well as air jitters to vacuum toxic gases from
            manholes. Solid waste burning will be prohibited, instead,
            wastes shall be incased, and transported to dumping sites
            (which should be fenced). Electricity poles to be relocated,
            or installed should be insulated, a practice to be followed
            by routine checks, and monitoring.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Emergency Municipal
            Services Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Municipal Services
            Rehabilitation Project will help mitigate further
            deterioration in the quality, and coverage of municipal
            services by: a) providing budgetary support for non-wage
            municipal operating costs, associated with essential service
            delivery; b) creating temporary labor-intensive employment
            opportunities; and, c) introducing a mechanism to link
            central, and local government budgetary planning processes,
            to strengthen Palestinian emergency response capacity,
            enhance mobilization of donor assistance, and improve the
            efficiency, and equity of resource transfers to local
            governments. It is expected that funds be fully disbursed by
            December 31st, 2004.
